properties.media:imagetext:
Chun king 1938
Feb. 28,
Mr.
M.
Bixby,
Manila, P. I.
Dear Mr. Bixby:
I have been trying for some time to get up
enough courage to
wite you a letter containing
something more, or less, than a
mere recital of the events of the day as they take place.
It is now just six months.
I landed in China on my return from the
the States and all my /ideas
on the situation out here are as
shifting now as
were then, probably more so. I have
tried. constantly to form/some
conclumion, even in the most
and indefinite terms, as to what the outcome
of the present
conditions in China would be, and how they would effect CNAC and
what would be
way to meet the situation, but so far 1
havent been able to reach any conclusion with sufficient clearness
to form a foundation for any particularly definite course of action.
About all I am really going on is hope, a term I use with full
consideration. Howeder in any circumstances you must haver some
plan of action however unsatisfactory. Ours is insecurely based
on the guess and bope method. We are simply living and working
to day. We are of course making every effort to be able
continue
this day to day existence as long in the future as
possible, but that
is as far as I have got up to now.
There have been many things in this war which have been a
disappointment
to me and of
course there have been some agreeable
surprises.
The Chinese people as a whole, according to my ideas,
are not
in this war and never have been.
Maybe it would be fairer
to say that the Chinese are very much in this war but their
resistance. has
been mostly passive resistance. But it is very
to win a war with passive resistance, particularly against
the Japanese. You may acquire many moral victories and
you may win
what comes after the war, although I question that also with the
Japanese. Also it/As difficult to win a xur modern war with coolies
mostly
grabbed up off the street. The upper and middle
class Chinese
yet realized that this is really their war and they have
to furnish the backbone
as well as the brains
of the
fighting 1f
they have any hope of winning, It is almost inconceivable for
nation to have beeniin such a war as this for seven months, with
its territory invaded and its poople to have
suffered
such
horrors
and barbarous treatment as the Chinese have and yet
not find
practically every ablebodied man between twenty and forty trying
to get into the army. But / do not know one
Chinese who has gone
into the fighting forces since this war started or who has a son
who has done so. I realize there must be many
of
the so called
better classes who are in the army but they are comparatively few.
